div1.head: Newspaper clipping, Boston Evening Transcript, December 24, 1901
div1.p:
The quality of self-sacrifice is determined
by the spirit in which it is performed,
rather than by the extent to which its
object is attained. But when conspicuous
self sacrifice results in great service, de-
liberately hoped for and enduring, it
makes a double appeal to human interest.
Such was the sacrifice made by Dr. Jesse
William Lazear, the young army surgeon,
who, with an equally devoted colleague,
voluntarily exposed himself to infection
by yellow fever in order that the knowl-
edge gained from his case might help to
establish those measures for preventing
the spread of yellow fever, which have
since been adopted with wonderful results.
His colleague took the fever and recov-
ered; Dr. Lazear took it and died.

Shortly after Dr. Lazear's death, which
occurred Sept. 25, 1900, a committee of his
colleagues and friends decided to raise
money for a memorial of his great sacri-
fice. It was Mrs. Lazear's wish that the
memorial to her husband should take a
permanent and useful form and that it
should be associated in some way with the
work of the Johns Hopkins Hospital. The
precise form of the memorial is not yet de-
termined, but the committee, which started
with a small number of contributions and
with modest hopes of what they could ac-
complish, have been so encouraged by the
interest which their plans have aroused
that they now hope to establish a travelling
scholarship. If the money raised should be
insufficient to endow such a scholarship, it
is proposed to establish a permanent
library fund at the hospital which should
be used especially for the purchase of
books on tropical diseases. Whatever the
decision may be, the money will be applied
is accordance with Mrs. Lazear's wish and
in the manner which seems, to the commit-
tee, to serve best the cause to which Dr.
Lazear gave his life.

Dr. Lazear's death inevitably gives in-
terest to the principal facts about his life.
He was born near Baltimore, in 1866; he
graduated from the academic department
of John Hopkins University in 1889, and
from the College of Physicians and Sur-
geons in New York in 1892; he spent two
years as an interne in Bellevue Hospital,
New York city, and one year in Europe;
during a part of 1895 and 1896 he was as-
sistant resident physician at the Johns
Hopkins Hospital. He was married in 1896,
and continued his connection with the hos-
pital as instructor in clinical microscopy
and as assistant in the dispensary; his
principal work was in the clinical labora-
tory, and he did valuable service as bac-
teriologist to the medical staff. The re-
sults of several of his investigations were
published, and he wrote the section on
diphtheria, plague, yellow fever and
cerebro-spinal meningitis, in Progressive
Medicine for March, 1899. (The credit for
this section was by mistake given to an-
other).

In the winter of 1900 he obtained an ap-
pointment in the army as acting assistant
surgeon with special laboratory duties, in
order that he might study malaria and
yellow fever in Cuba, and continue work
which he had begun on the structure of
the malarial parasite. Later he was ap-
pointed with Drs. Reed and Carroll to
serve on the Government commission for
the study of yellow fever; and in this work
his previous knowledge of mosquitoes
proved of great value. The commission
convinced themselves that a definite rela-
tion existed between mosquitoes and the
transmission of yellow fever. The three
members of the commission, therefore,
agreed to subject themselves to the bites
of mosquitoes which had previously bitten
yellow fever patients. Dr. Reed was called
away to Washington, but Drs. Lazear and
Carroll submitted to the experiment. Dr.
Carroll developed yellow fever and recov-
ered; Dr. Lazear at first escaped infection,
apparently because the mosquito which
had bitten him had not been kept a suffi-
cient length of time; but subsequently,
while working in a yellow fever ward, he
allowed another mosquito to alight upon
his arm, and, knowing that it would in all
probability carry infection, he decided to
try the experiment again. Three days later
the symptoms of yellow fever appeared,
and he died of the disease. The conclu-
sions drawn from these two cases were
borne out by subsequent investigations, and
they have already brought about results
of incalculable importance, both to Cuba
and to the United States.

Dr. Lazear was a pure, upright and
able man, and would undoubtedly have
made a mark in his profession had he been
spared for longer service. He left a wife
and two little children.

Any persons who feel interested in the
objects of this memorial and wish to have
a part in perpetuating the influence of Dr.
Lazear's self-sacrifice are requested to
send contributions to Mr. Charles Francis
Adams, 2d, 23 Court street, Boston, who
has kindly consented to receive such con-
tributions on behalf of the committee.
John Hogan Sent to State Prison

In the Superior Criminal Court, yester-
day afternoon, Judge Lawton presiding,
John Hogan, the South Boston real estate
dealer who last week pleaded guilty to
larceny in two counts, involving the misuse
of $100 and $200 respectively, belonging to
clients, was sentenced to serve from three
to five years at hard labor in the State
prison. Nearly all his victims were persons
who could ill afford to lose what Hogan ob-
tained from them by false representations.
It was argued in Hogan's favor by his
counsel that the cases, such as they were,
were not criminal but civil in character.
